question: To become rock, sediments must generally be what?

content.source_1: Clastic sedimentary rocks (shales, siltstones, sandstones) are the most abundant sedimentary rock types by volume in the geologic record.
content.source_2: Lithification of clastic sediments typically involves burial compaction—overlying weight squeezes grains together and expels pore water—often followed by mineral cementation.
content.source_3: In many shallow‑marine carbonate settings, sediments can lithify rapidly through early cementation at or just below the seafloor, before substantial burial occurs.
content.source_4: Early carbonate cementation rigidifies the sediment framework and largely inhibits later mechanical compaction during burial.
content.source_5: Long intervals in numerous basins are dominated by thick carbonate platform successions (limestone and dolostone).
